headline: Forged in the Same Political Caldron, Now Pursuing Their Own Paths

headline: Revamped Nets Feel Like a Good Fit in Striving Newark

headline: Nets Win Opener Over Pistons but Admit It’s Still Early

headline: Johnson Seems Unbeatable as Chase Nears the Midpoint

headline: A Battle Over Uranium Bodes Ill for U.S. Debate

headline: To See a Universe in the Tiny Details of Chinese Artifacts, Boxes to Birds

headline: JUSTEN LADDA: ‘7 Mirrors and a Nose’

headline: Brice Marden: ‘Letters,’ and ‘Paintings 1961-1964’

snippet: A roundup of art books selected by The Times critics Holland Cotter, Roberta Smith, Ken Johnson and Karen Rosenberg.

headline: The Rise of the Tao

headline: The Volcker Rule After the Midterm Elections

headline: Desirée Rogers, Post Crash

headline: A Draftsman Who Turned More and More to Dynamism

headline: Tea Party Triumphs in Rural Colorado

headline: Bennet Declares Victory in Colorado Senate Race

snippet: The F.D.A.’s principal deputy commissioner contradicted assertions by Johnson & Johnson executives that the problems had been more limited.
headline: Official Says J.&J. Plants Had Widespread Failings

snippet: Next door to the Obamas’ Chicago home, there are blockades at each end of the block, and signs warn contractors that they need permission from federal authorities to go any farther.
headline: A Gut Renovation, With the Secret Service Watching

snippet: Representative John Salazar and his challenger Scott Tipton in Colorado’s Third Congressional District have a get-out-the-vote challenge in a sprawling district.
headline: Pledging Independence to Voters Here and Yon

snippet: In testimony on Thursday, William C. Weldon will seek to reassure the public after broad recalls, and defend his stewardship of the consumer products company.
headline: After Recalls of Drugs, a Congressional Spotlight on J.& J.’s Chief

snippet: Most people assume that market forces drive inventions. But over the last two centuries, collaborative, nonproprietary innovation has eclipsed, and transformed, the marketplace.
headline: Innovation: It Isn’t a Matter of Left or Right

snippet: Show: William Lamson
headline: William Lamson: ‘A Line Describing the Sun’

snippet: Running a positive campaign may have insulated John Hickenlooper, the Democratic candidate for Colorado’s governor, from the need to make his opponents bleed.
headline: Vow Against Attack Ads Resonates in Colorado

headline: The New Global Creditors and Instability

headline: Period Rooms Take on a Modern Gloss

snippet: Western classical music in China seems to begin and end with the big Romantic stars of the 19th century.
headline: Going Baroque in China

snippet: Senator Michael Bennet is focusing on women, gay men and lesbians, and the Democratic Party base in trying to fend off Ken Buck.
headline: Small Efforts Add Up in Colorado Senate Race

snippet: Two longtime executives, Alex Gorsky and Sheri S. McCoy, have been given expanded roles in the troubled health care company.
headline: 2 in Race to Lead Johnson & Johnson

snippet: Paul Johnson’s biographical essays on humorists include obvious selections (Dickens, Chaplin) and some curious ones.
headline: What’s So Funny?

snippet: Long a feature of purely internal-combustion vehicles in Europe, start-stop technology is beginning to find an American audience.
headline: Start-Stop Technology: Not Just for Hybrids Anymore

snippet: Robert Formola, who sustained a fractured skull at a Jets game in Indianapolis in January, spent last Sunday as the team’s guest in Pittsburgh.
headline: Fan’s Unforgettable Day, in Year He’d Like to Forget

snippet: A popular feminine hygiene product has been noticeably disappearing from store shelves, without a definite explanation.
headline: The Case of the Missing o.b. Tampons

snippet: In 2010, some athletes celebrated, but for others, there was much disappointment.
headline: A Year of Milestones and Millstones

snippet: Andrew Johnson, the man who would later succeed Lincoln, made his name with a startling speech about secession.
headline: The Tailor Draws a Line

snippet: In congressman’s letter to the F.D.A., the Best Sweet plant in Mooresville, N.C., is revealed as the maker of millions of Rolaids recalled by Johnson & Johnson.

snippet: The British do many things well, but handling snow does not seem to be one of them.
headline: Ill Prepared for Snowfall, Britain Crawls to a Halt

snippet: DePuy’s artificial hip was marketed in the United States with a crucial component that had not been rigorously tested in patients.
headline: The Implants Loophole

headline: After Months in Limbo, Paterson Aide Charged in Abuse Case Is Fired

snippet: Playing like anything but the cellar-dweller they are, the Nets battled the defending champion Lakers basket for basket in a 99-92 loss.
headline: The Nets Give the Lakers All That They Can Handle

snippet: Bills receiver Steve Johnson may be taking more criticism for how he’s handling his  dropped pass against the Steelers  than for  the drop itself.
headline: Bills’ Steve Johnson Can’t Get Past Missed Catch

snippet: From a shirt naming rights deal with Barcelona, to a first-place tie in the Premier League, the region is increasing its profile in world soccer.

snippet: Plaintiffs around the country contended that they suffered tendon injuries upon taking the antibiotic.
headline: Verdict Against J.&J. in Levaquin Case

snippet: Johnson & Johnson made a formal offer on Wednesday for Crucell, a Dutch biotechnology company.
headline: J.&J. Bids $2.3 Billion for Crucell

snippet: Joseph Bramlett’s background matches with Tiger Woods’s in a number of ways, but he has yet to hit a shot on the PGA Tour.

headline: Laughing Matters: Discuss

headline: Johnson Is Nascar’s Dynasty of One

headline: For Pentagon Lawyer Who Co-Wrote Report on Gays, Military Bias Hits Home

headline: Chalmers Johnson Dies at 79; Criticized U.S. Role in World

snippet: “Thomas Lanigan-Schmidt: Tender Love Among the Junk,” a retrospective at MoMA PS1, assembles discardable elements into sexual and religious works.
headline: The Alchemy of Debris Forged Into Passion

snippet: Construction will begin next year on a series of tightly coordinated engineering works, including a traffic tunnel and an earthquake-conscious sea wall.
headline: Engineering Projects Will Transform Seattle, All Along the Waterfront

snippet: The filing by A123 Systems dealt a blow to the Obama administration’s program to jump-start a domestic battery industry and spur development of electric vehicles.
headline: Maker of Batteries Files for Bankruptcy

snippet: The first night at Barclays Center was mostly a success, and even the visiting Washington Wizards were impressed.
headline: Nets Settling Into Their Home

snippet: Perhaps the most valuable experience of the three-day donor retreat in New York City came on Tuesday afternoon when the more than 1,000 donors present kicked-off a speed call-a-thon, with a goal of raising more than $2 million.
headline: Romney Donors Meet to Schmooze . . . and Raise More

snippet: The Americans’ hunt for goals has led them back to Johnson, who has been called up to the national team for the first time since 2010.
headline: New Answer for U.S. Team May be an Old One: Eddie Johnson

snippet: In three separate galleries White Columns features works by the painter Jane Corrigan, paintings by the cultural critic Wayne Koestenbaum and sculptures by Joe Fyfe, also known for his plain-spoken art criticism.
headline: Wayne Koestenbaum, Jane Corrigan, Joe Fyfe

snippet: The opportunity to choose strong reformers to head key agencies may yield to the goal of pleasing prominent people in the financial sector, an economist writes.
headline: Dropping the Ball on Financial Regulation

snippet: Concerned that the Libertarian presidential candidate Gary Johnson could hurt the Romney campaign, Republicans across the country have been working to keep him off the ballot.
headline: Spoiler Alert! G.O.P. Fighting Libertarian’s Spot on the Ballot

snippet: An invitation for a fund-raiser featuring Paul D. Ryan lists a number of prominent hedge fund and private equity executives, underscoring the support that the Romney campaign is receiving from the upper echelons of Wall Street.
headline: Wall Street’s Fund-Raising Push for Romney

snippet: The mod designer has a new fashion line and a reality TV show.
headline: Betsey Johnson, Back in the Pink

snippet: “Buddy and Jim” by Buddy Miller and Jim Lauderdale, and “Elevated Vegetation” by the Max Johnson Trio.
headline: Albums from Buddy Miller and Jim Lauderdale, and the Max Johnson Trio

snippet: After Nets guard Deron Williams proclaimed himself uncomfortable in Coach Avery Johnson’s offense, both player and coach downplayed the comments.
headline: Williams, Johnson Play Down Rift over Nets Offense

snippet: Joe Johnson scored 28 points, including the game-winning shot as time expired, in the Nets’ victory over the Pistons in double overtime.
headline: Johnson Rescues Ragged Nets by Beating Buzzer and Pistons

snippet: Mr. Johnson — a war hero, police officer, crusader against Tammany Hall and lawyer — led a battle against union bosses who colluded with gangsters.
headline: Peter Johnson, Crusader Against Corruption, Dies at 91

snippet: In deliberately tight quarters, Ryan Johnson’s sculptures at Suzanne Geiss Company evoke objects that might be found in a storage unit.
headline: Ryan Johnson: ‘Self Storage’

snippet: The drug, to be called Sirturo, was discovered by scientists at Janssen, the pharmaceuticals unit of Johnson & Johnson, and is the first in a new class of drugs that aims to treat the drug-resistant strain of the disease.
headline: F.D.A. Approves Drug for Resistant Tuberculosis

snippet: Despite the Nets’ franchise-best start, recent turmoil led Nets ownership to dispatch Coach Avery Johnson.
headline: Suddenly Reeling, the Nets Fire Their Coach

snippet: Point guard Deron Williams said Friday that he did not quit on Avery Johnson, but he did accept some responsibility for the Nets’ poor play recently.
headline: Williams Dismisses View That He Caused Coach’s Firing

snippet: Rex Ryan on Friday denounced a report that said he would welcome being fired if owner Woody Johnson doesn’t upgrade the offense.
headline: Ryan Wants to Be Jets Coach for ‘Next 15 Years’

snippet: The Jets were 57-55 in seven seasons under Mike Tannenbaum, reaching the N.F.L. playoffs three times — but not since 2010.
headline: Ryan Stays; Tannenbaum Goes; Other Answers Are Scarce

snippet: After being dismissed from previous N.B.A. coaching stints, including with Golden State, where he was infamously choked by Latrell Sprewell, P.J. Carlesimo will take over as the Nets’ interim coach.
headline: Putting ‘the Choke’ Further in the Past

snippet: A challenge to create the ultimate housework workout.
headline: Buffing Up the Butler

snippet: Reaction to the dismissal of Coach Avery Johnson by the Nets, whose owner made it clear he wants to win right away.
headline: Nets Coach Undone by a Fast Clock

snippet: Interim Coach P. J. Carlesimo is on the bench for now, and he guided the Nets to an easy win on Friday, but Brooklyn has firmly targeted Phil Jackson to take over.
headline: Nets Beat the Bobcats but Pine for Jackson

snippet: Johnson & Johnson said Alex Gorsky, its chief executive, would succeed William C. Weldon, who will step down after 41 years with the pharmaceutical company.
headline: Johnson & Johnson Names New Chairman

snippet: Joe Johnson scored 22 points and the Nets, who had lost 8 of 10 coming into the game, repelled a late charge by Philadelphia.
headline: New Lineup Without Humphries Has a Surging Start

snippet: In explaining the Nets’ 13-12 slump, Joe Johnson said a lack of sticking to defensive plays has hurt them. Coach Avery Johnson pointed to a need for more trust among his players.
headline: Guard Says Nets Aren’t Following Schemes; Coach Cites Trust

snippet: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
headline: GTT ★

snippet: The National Rifle Association didn’t take any questions at its press conference last Friday, but there were plenty of harsh words on Twitter, many from celebrities.
headline: No Questions on N.R.A. Plan, but Plenty of Comments

snippet: The verb “to Bork” may seem like a dig at an honored martyr of the right, but the campaign to defeat him was neither unprecedented nor illegitimate.
headline: ‘Borking’ Before Bork

headline: Frustrating Game, Week and Month

headline: Nets’ Early Success Earns Johnson Coach of the Month Honor

snippet: Deron Williams, who is is averaging 17 points and 8.3 assists while shooting 38.8 percent from the field, said the offense he ran in Utah was a better fit for him than the Nets’ system.
headline: Misfiring Williams Takes Shot at the Nets’ System

snippet: It has been easier to be a fan of the Broncos or the Clippers this year.
headline: A Tough Season to Be a Nets or Jets Fan

snippet: Brook Lopez of the Nets, who has missed the last seven games, is listed as probable for Friday night’s game against the Pistons.
headline: Lopez Hopes to Play Friday Night

snippet: The Los Angeles Dodgers, trying to catch up to the top teams quickly, will almost surely have the highest payroll in baseball history in 2013.
headline: In Payroll, Dodgers Tell Yankees to Move Over

snippet: The mayor of London invites Indian talent to the United Kingdom.
headline: Boris Johnson Woos Delhi

snippet: The Bronx district attorney had argued that a gang met the somewhat vague definition of “terror” in the state statute because it sought to intimidate or coerce an entire population.
headline: Court Rules Gang Crime Falls Short of Terrorism

snippet: Chris Bliss, a juggler and stand-up comedian, set out to build a monument to the Bill of Rights. On Saturday, his vision will be unveiled in Phoenix.
headline: Religious Monument Gets a Sidekick: Bill of Rights

snippet: The new $100,000 award was established in September by Jean Kennedy Smith to honor her brother Edward M. Kennedy.
headline: Finalists Named for Kennedy Theater Prize

snippet: Small but significant declines in childhood obesity offer the first indication that one of the nation’s most intractable health problems may be reversing course.
headline: Obesity in Young Is Seen as Falling in Several Cities

snippet: Jeh C. Johnson, the Obama administration’s top lawyer at the Pentagon, will step down at the end of December, the military said on Thursday.
headline: Washington: Pentagon’s Top Lawyer Is Leaving

snippet: Jeh C. Johnson has been a central player in legal debates over drone strikes and the detention and trial of terrorism suspects.
headline: Pentagon’s Top Lawyer to Resign

snippet: The auction for the bankrupt battery maker A123 is under way, and at least four companies have qualified to bid, according to Inside E.V.’s.
headline: Wheelies: The Battery-Powered Edition

snippet: In Davey Johnson’s quest to lead the Washington Nationals to a championship in his last season as a manager, the team has added the veteran pitcher Dan Haren to its already loaded rotation.
headline: ‘World Series or Bust’ for Nationals

snippet: During his rookie season, Detroit wide receiver Calvin Johnson was nicknamed Megatron, an evil character from the Transformers, but the moniker doesn’t quite fit his vast powers on the football field.
headline: As Lions’ Star Heats Up, Few Labels Seem Accurate to Describe Him

snippet: While Brook Lopez nursed an ankle injury and Deron Williams had a subpar game, another Nets pair led them to victory over the Magic on Friday night.
headline: Half of the Nets’ Core Four Provide Enough for a Win

snippet: When the war against Al Qaeda winds down, the responsibility for mopping up scattered remnants of the group will likely fall to United States law enforcement and intelligence agencies.
headline: Pentagon Counsel Speaks of Post-Qaeda Challenges

snippet: Duke Energy’s chairman and chief executive, James E. Rogers, will retire at the end of 2013 as part of a wide-ranging settlement with regulators in North Carolina.
headline: Duke Energy’s Latest C.E.O. Drama

snippet: The Celtics have dominated the Atlantic Division for the last half decade, but with the Nets on the rise, that could be coming to an end.
headline: Among the Pushes and Shoves, a Possible Shift in Power

snippet: With 273 yards on 14 receptions, the Texans’ Andre Johnson set a personal record for receiving yards, and it was his final catch of the game that was his most impressive.
headline: Breaking Down Andre Johnson’s Winning Catch

snippet: The feud started when Jenny Johnson, a comic from Houston, took a potshot at Chris Brown and his 2009 assault on then-girlfriend Rihanna.
headline: Chris Brown Signs Off

snippet: President Barack Obama should take John A. Boehner, the House speaker, to the new movie "Lincoln" to learn how bargaining is used to reach noble ends.
headline: Learning From Lincoln

snippet: Over the last two years Woody Johnson has balanced twin pursuits, owning one of the N.F.L.’s more valuable franchises and serving as a critical member of Mitt Romney’s campaign fund-raising team.
headline: 2 Bruising Sports Tantalize Jets’ Owner: Football and Politics

snippet: From Senator Richard G. Lugar’s foreign policy expertise to Senator Kent Conrad’s bichon frisé, the expiring Congress has left its mark in ways large, small and weird.
headline: Members of the 112th Congress Depart, Taking Their Quirks Along

snippet: Brad Keselowski needed to bring his Dodge home in at least 15th in Sunday’s final Nascar Sprint Cup race of the season and that is exactly what he did, to win the 2012 season points championship.
headline: 2012 Nascar Sprint Cup Champions: Keselowski, Penske and Dodge

snippet: The biggest difference right now between the Nets and the Celtics? Boston’s leaders have seen their system work.
headline: Nets See ‘Celtics Way’ as Something to Emulate

snippet: For the second time in the still-young hot stove season, the Blue Jays have turned themselves into something to talk about by signing outfielder Melky Cabrera to a free-agent contract.
headline: Who Woke Up the Blue Jays?

snippet: The Nets withstood a second-half Celtics rally, and two late baskets by their marquee off-season acquisition, Joe Johnson, were fitting in a tough early season test.
headline: The Nets Rise High and See It as a Springboard

snippet: Woody Johnson said he was not happy with the Jets’ performance this season, and refused to evaluate the performances of Mark Sanchez, Rex Ryan and Mike Tannenbaum.
headline: No Votes of Confidence From Jets Owner

snippet: Tradition prevailed in deciding that Miguel Cabrera was the American League most valuable player, and Buster Posey won in the N.L. without debate.
headline: M.V.P. Voters Trust Their Eyes

snippet: The baseball commissioner said he would review Miami’s trade of top talent for Toronto prospects, but he noted that “clubs have to make their own decisions.”
headline: Reviewing Marlins Deal, Selig Expresses Caution

snippet: It is worth reveling in R.A. Dickey’s Cy Young Award — and wondering (again) what exactly is going on with the Jets.
headline: Knuckleballs and Knuckleheads

snippet: Deron Williams scored a season-high 26 points in Tuesday night’s victory over Cleveland, even as tough frontcourt players, like Anderson Varejao, gave the Nets a bit of trouble.
headline: A Win Reveals Some of the Nets’ Weaknesses

snippet: Davey Johnson of the Nationals and Bob Melvin of the Athletics won Manager of the Year awards on Tuesday for their roles in leading their franchises to overdue playoff berths.
headline: Managers Who Ended Postseason Droughts Receive Honors

snippet: Sportswriters spared no outrage for the Marlins owner Jeffrey Loria after the team’s latest fire sale left even his remaining players venting.
headline: Trading Away the Marlins’ Dignity

snippet: In a multiplayer trade, the Marlins sent five players, including shortstop Jose Reyes and the starting pitchers Mark Buehrle and Josh Johnson, to the Blue Jays for a group of prospects.
headline: Marlins Pull the Plug Again

snippet: J.C. Penney reported last week that its sales had fallen 26.1 percent in the most recent quarter, but Ronald B. Johnson, its chief executive, promoted the success of the company’s store renovation plan.
headline: A Dose of Realism for the Chief of J.C. Penney

snippet: The AdvoCare 500 in Phoenix erupted in a brawl after Jeff Gordon crashed into Clint Bowyer.
headline: Motorsports Monday: Keselowski Builds Sprint Cup Lead

snippet: If the now-3-6 Jets continue to fade, there are bound to be repercussions, but a select few will likely bare the brunt.
headline: In Analyzing Jets’ Failings, Start at the Top

snippet: The franchise received plenty of attention for moving to Brooklyn, but a subsequent 1-2 start, including a 30-point loss against the Heat, has not gone unnoticed.
headline: Nets Are Caught Between Hype and a Slow Start

snippet: Two women, decades apart in age but bonded by their relative invisibility, connect in Sean Baker’s “Starlet.”
headline: Less Than Visible, but Not to Each Other

snippet: Johnson holds a 2-point lead over Brad Keselowski with three races left in the season’s 36-race schedule.
headline: Motorsports: Jimmie Johnson Takes Nascar Points Lead

snippet: William D. Johnson, the ousted chief executive of Duke Energy, was named the new head of the Tennessee Valley Authority, the government-created provider of wholesale power in Tennessee and parts of six other southern states.
headline: Ousted Duke Energy Chief Named Head of Tennessee Utility

snippet: At her federal trial in Brooklyn, Cecilia Chang, who led the  Asian Studies Institute at St. John’s University, acknowledged many of the acts she is accused of.
headline: Ex-Dean Denies She Stole From St. John’s

snippet: Kimi Raikkonen won a crash-filled race for Lotus on Sunday in the Abu Dhabi Grand Prix, while Sebastian Vettel held on to the Formula One championship points lead.
headline: Monday Motorsports: Alonso and Vettel in Red-Hot F1 Points Battle

snippet: At a Washington coffeehouse, four third-party candidates sparred at an event moderated by the most famous third-party candidate in recent memory, Ralph Nader.
headline: Another Presidential Debate, but This Time the Candidates Are Much Less Familiar

snippet: Bill Simmons, who will appear on ESPN’s “NBA Countdown” this season, has good things to say about the Heat, the Hawks, the Lakers and, of course, the Celtics.
headline: Bill Simmons Has a New TV Gig, and Some N.B.A. Predictions

snippet: The Ford Motor Company said on Monday that it was selling a climate-control unit to a joint venture between Valeo of France and V. Johnson Enterprises for an undisclosed price, completing Ford’s plan to sell off a collection of auto parts manufact...
headline: Ford Sells Climate-Control Unit

snippet: Jamey Johnson, Rez Abbasi Trio, Cody Chesnutt, Flying Lotus and Angelica Sanchez release new music.
headline: The Sounds Are Familiar, but Under New Ownership

snippet: State Representative Dan Branch, who heads the House Higher Education Committee, hopes that the lower numbers will help him change the higher education financing system.
headline: Amid Slowing College Enrollment, Fears of Missing Goals

snippet: The Bronx candidates include a union organizer, a criminal defense lawyer, a bus company owner, an economic-policy adviser, an Anglican minister and a community center director.
headline: 6 Are Seeking Council Seat One Man Held for a Decade

snippet: The climate debate seems loud and momentous up close, but is consistently lost in the din of daily news.
headline: One Reason for Debate Climate Silence

snippet: Chris McCaw’s prints in “Marking Time,” now showing at Yossi Milo, suggest photography manipulated to have an antique look.
headline: Chris McCaw: ‘Marking Time’

snippet: Neil Barofsky’s track record and unimpeachable integrity make him the ideal choice to oversee enforcement at the Securities and Exchange Commission, an economist writes.
headline: The S.E.C. at a Turning Point

snippet: One of the creators of a new majority coalition said state politics had become too “Seattle-centric,” too liberal to be representative of Washington as a whole.
headline: Washington State Senators Cross Aisle and Tilt Ideological Balance

snippet: After Sunday’s practice, Nets Coach Avery Johnson said that his team didn’t have a “hit-first mentality,” a concern that sounded like an alarm bell with 11 days to go until opening night.
headline: With Nets’ Roles Undecided, a Focus on Attitude

snippet: Backed by influential investors, a Washington company intends, within a decade or so, to have an unmanned robotic mining mission to the asteroid belt.
headline: A Start-Up Sees a Gold Rush Among the Stars

snippet: A snow camping trip in the Adirondacks helped a documentary filmmaker living in New York City return to her country roots.
headline: On Skis, Sharpening a Relationship With Risk

snippet: Alicja Kwade, a cerebrally imaginative artist, produces elegantly understated works that are as much thought experiments as sculptures.
headline: Alicja Kwade: ‘The Heavy Weight of Light’

snippet: Terry Allen favors a funky mix of drawing, writing, sculpture and multimedia installation that combines comedy and tragedy, realistic grit and visionary imagination.
headline: Terry Allen: ‘Ghosts: Works From “Dugout”/ “Ghost Ship Rodez”/ and Others’

snippet: The new exhibition on Louis C. Tiffany samples the Tiffany Studios’ enormous production of stained-glass windows as well as all kinds of other church-related objects.
headline: Spiritual Landscapes of the Gilded Age

snippet: A cynical effort by the biggest banks to derail limitations on risk taking misrepresents American obligations abroad, an economist writes.
headline: Last-Ditch Attempt to Derail Volcker Rule

snippet: The work of Trisha Baga — her video projections, paintings, sculptures and scattered objects — is being showcased at two museums and a gallery in New York.
headline: Vying for Fluency in Many Languages

snippet: Staff Sgt. Robert Bales acted deliberately when he killed 16 civilians in Afghanistan, the Army says, but his lawyer suggested there were questions about his mental health.
headline: Army Seeking Death Penalty in Massacre of 16 Afghans

snippet: Joe Johnson, acquired by the Nets from Atlanta, is eager to shed his reputation for commanding the basketball and be the complementary player he was with Phoenix.
headline: As a Net, Johnson Is Relearning to Share

snippet: Some hard-line conservatives still distressed over the re-election of President Obama have made their displeasure known by hanging upside-down American flags in their yard.
headline: Symbol of Pride, Inverted, Is Now Symbol of Political Dismay

snippet: Judith Bernstein, in her first solo show in a museum, has seven works from 1966 to 2012 in the New Museum’s lobby gallery.
headline: Once Banished, Never Silenced

snippet: New rules in the federal retirement system are forcing sweeping changes at Alaska’s parks and preserves as scores of top officials take early retirement.

snippet: Keltie Ferris uses the old-fashioned art of painting to evoke a kind of vision made possible by new electronic technology.

headline: Scott Dixon Wins Third IndyCar Title

snippet: “See It Loud: Seven Post-War American Painters,” running through Jan. 26 at the National Academy Museum, features works from the collection of a former trustee, Henry Justin.
headline: Representational Work in Years When Abstract Was Hot

snippet: Mayor-elect Ed Murray of Seattle, who ran on a pledge backing a $15 minimum wage, said he planned to propose legislation to the City Council by spring.
headline: Washington: Seattle Mayor Forms Panel to Look at Incomes

snippet: “Brancusi in New York 1913 — 2013” and “Arman the Collector: The Artist’s Collection of African Art” showcase tribal art.
headline: A Tension Between the Sacred and the Profane

snippet: The Puget Sound’s identity as an aviation hub is being threatened by Boeing’s decision to consider other incentive offers as it decides where to manufacture a new plane.
headline: Boeing Looks Around, and a State Worries

snippet: While toying with signs in familiar Pop Art style, Mr. Strother also is doing something specifically African-American: “signifying.”
headline: Devin Troy Strother: ‘I Just Landed in Rome’

snippet: “Danish Paintings From the Golden Age to the Modern Breakthough,” at Scandinavia House, traces a growing dialogue between native restraint and early modern French currents.
headline: Desire and Prudery, Wrestling to a Draw

snippet: The key to Jill Magid’s exquisitely sly exhibition is in a pair of letters displayed at the start.
headline: Jill Magid: ‘Woman With Sombrero’

snippet: Efforts to repeal a new, more lenient tax law on oil profits in Alaska are stirring up a strange political cocktail, in which Democrats find themselves backing Sarah Palin.
headline: Alaska Democrats See a Palin Legacy They Can Like

snippet: A measure giving the city the highest minimum wage in the nation has passed narrowly, but opponents vow to keep fighting it.
headline: Voters in SeaTac, Wash., Back $15 Minimum Wage

snippet: This exhibition of new work by the internationally admired German conceptualist Rosemarie Trockel has three parts, one good, two not so good.
headline: Rosemarie Trockel

snippet: Two exhibitions at the Drawing Center showcase the look of writings and drawings above the meanings.
headline: When How It Looks Matters More Than What It Says

snippet: Ms. Marder specializes in the tricky photographic terrain where sociology and slumming and intimacy and voyeurism meet and overlap.

headline: Poignant Images, With Posterity the Ultimate Winner

snippet: The way the Pell grant program is designed makes it harder for low-income students to graduate on schedule.

snippet: China’s government-led urbanization, meant to solve one problem, may be creating a new set of troubles that could plague Chinese cities for generations.

headline: Steve Mumford: ‘The Snow Leopard’

snippet: “Silla: Korea’s Golden Kingdom,” at the Metropolitan Museum, demonstrates how a long-running dynasty, little known in the West, got its nickname.
headline: A Mysterious Realm of Exquisite Objects

snippet: Mike McGinn, who was elected mayor in 2009, was denied a second term on Tuesday as voters turned instead to Ed Murray, a longtime state senator.
headline: A Familiar Result in Seattle, as Voters Oust Mayor for the Third Time in 12 Years

snippet: Pocatello, a railroad town, welcomed a Chinese polysilicon factory with a land deal, banking on a high-tech future. But the company filed for bankruptcy.
headline: Idaho Town Struggles After Pinning Hopes on a Failed Factory

snippet: On the eve of Election Day, polls suggested that Mayor Mike McGinn was in trouble, even though the economy is doing pretty well and job numbers are growing.
headline: Seattle’s Mayor Faces Challenge, Despite Signs of Success

snippet: David Shaw’s beautiful, trippy exhibition occupies the main gallery at the Feature Inc. gallery.

snippet: “Designing Modern Women 1890-1990,” at the Museum of Modern Art, examines how women helped shape future ways of living and served as muses to modernity.
headline: Shaping the Future, in the Kitchen and Beyond

snippet: Voters will decide whether Washington will become the first state to require the labeling of genetically engineered foods, but food companies are fighting the measure.

headline: Arthur C. Danto, a Philosopher of Art, Is Dead at 89

headline: Carlyle Said in Talks for Johnson & Johnson Unit

snippet: The crew on Pharrell Williams’s 24-hour “Happy” video were overwhelmed when the production moved into Magic Johnson’s trophy room.

snippet: The Tony Feher retrospective at the Bronx Museum of the Arts features his sculptural configurations of wine bottles, bottle tops, pieces of glass and rope, and other detritus.

snippet: The government shutdown 4,000 miles away in Washington prevented Alaska’s king-crab fishing fleet from opening the season, which could leave holiday tables wanting and fishermen poorer.

snippet: Tom Brady was sacked three times early, and the Jets, although booed multiple times, led entering the fourth quarter. But a conversion of a third-and-7 helped the Patriots seal the victory.
headline: Jets Keep Patriots at Bay, Then Revert to Type Against Their Rivals

snippet: For a fleeting moment last spring, the epidemic sweeping West Africa might have been stopped. But the opportunity to control the virus, which has now caused more than 7,800 deaths, was lost.
headline: How Ebola Roared Back

snippet: David Blatt, Cleveland’s coach, shook up his starting lineup by adding Mike Miller, and Miller promptly scored 21 points in a victory over the undermanned Nets.
headline: Cavaliers Mix It Up and Edge Nets

snippet: The report released by the Department of Homeland Security also said the next director should come from outside the agency.
headline: Secret Service, Stretched Too Thin, Needs More Agents, Report Says

snippet: A group of experts advising the Secret Service on how to provide better protection to the White House has offered its recommendations, and topping the list is a taller fence.
headline: Step One for Securing the White House? A Higher Fence

snippet: Steve Johnson, the president and chief executive during the rampant doping of the Lance Armstrong era, will leave after the world championships next fall.
headline: Executive’s Ride Into Sunset Signals Brighter Day for U.S.A. Cycling

snippet: The secretary of Homeland Security told a crowd in South Texas that a new facility, especially designed for women and children, should help deter illegal border crossings.
headline: Detention Center Presented as Deterrent to Border Crossings

snippet: President Obama’s surprise announcement on Wednesday that he is restoring diplomatic relations with Cuba touched off a political storm, and the repercussions will undoubtedly be felt through 2016 and beyond.
headline: Today in Politics

snippet: Charles C. Johnson, a blogger based in California, may be the ultimate expression of a certain kind of citizen journalism — one far more toxic than we’re accustomed to seeing.
headline: Sowing Mayhem, One Click at a Time

snippet: Now with the Jets, running back Chris Johnson said that the decision to leave Tennessee was not his, but that he did not expect Titans fans to give him a break.
headline: A Back Returns to a Place He Never Wanted to Leave

snippet: The Black Knights did a lot of things right but fell to the Midshipmen in the 115th meeting between the teams.
headline: Navy Regroups to Beat Army for 13th Straight Game

snippet: Frustrated by how little they earn, the ablest farmers have migrated to cities, hollowing out rural districts in the Chinese heartland.
headline: Once a Symbol of Power, Farming Now an Economic Drag in China

snippet: Patricia M. Vroom contends her career nearly collapsed when she raised legal concerns about a policy of prosecutorial discretion she was ordered to apply to spare some immigrants from deportation.
headline: Lawsuit Against ICE Previews Turmoil That Immigration Overhaul May Cause Its Enforcers

snippet: The hospital said it would halt injections of a vaccine licensed to Merck until next month, after some test subjects reported mild joint pain.
headline: Hospital Pauses Test of an Ebola Vaccine Licensed to Merck

snippet: The founder of Gawker Media said he would remain the company’s chief executive, but recent failures had shown he needed more support.
headline: Nick Denton Reorganizes Gawker to Share Managerial Responsibilities

snippet: In “The Forever Now,” MoMA offers a long-awaited exhibition about the state of current painting.
headline: The Paintbrush in the Digital Era

snippet: London’s mayor, an American citizen, goes mano a mano with the Internal Revenue Service. He should give up and pay up.
headline: Get Real, Boris Johnson!

snippet: Onerous and outdated tax-filing requirements make life very difficult for American expatriates.
headline: Why I’m Giving Up My Passport

snippet: Critics say a decree by President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf of Liberia that bans all political rallies in Monrovia to prevent the further spread of Ebola is really an attempt to ensure victory for her son’s Senate campaign.
headline: Liberian President’s Ban on Rallies Is Seen as Political

snippet: Cylvia Hayes, the wife of Gov. John Kitzhaber, said she married her third husband, an Ethiopian immigrant, for money in a sham marriage in 1997.
headline: Oregon First Lady’s Ex-Marriage Spills Into Race for Governor

snippet: In issuing the crowd-control order, President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf argued that large concentrations of people at election rallies were precisely the situations that could spawn new infections.
headline: Liberia Bans Election Rallies to Fight Ebola

snippet: The Republicans, at a hearing, accused the administration of trying to do an end run around Congress.
headline: House Republicans and White House Clash on Obama Immigration Plan

snippet: In testimony before a House committee, Jeh C. Johnson, the secretary of Homeland Security, called President Obama’s executive action on immigration “common sense.”
headline: Homeland Security Chief on Immigration

snippet: Portland’s fondness for bikes, literary culture and liberal impulses have come together with Street Books, a nonprofit book service for “people living outside.”
headline: Homeless Outreach in Volumes: Books by Bike for ‘Outside’ People in Oregon

snippet: In her show at Tanya Bondakar, Agnieszka Kurant uses an autopen signature machine and a community of termites to explore the notion of phantom entities.
headline: Agnieszka Kurant: ‘Variables’

snippet: Jeh C. Johnson, the Homeland Security secretary, is prepared to defend the president’s decision to take executive action to overhaul the immigration system.
headline: Homeland Security Chief Set to Defend Immigration Action

snippet: Denis Johnson’s “The Laughing Monsters” reads like a mash-up of African novels by Conrad and Greene.
headline: Liars Bound for Heart of Dimness

snippet: The exhibition “Puddle, pothole, portal,” at SculptureCenter in Long Island City, Queens, presents visual and conceptual humor in works by 23 artists.
headline: The Art of Funny: Cartoon Imagery, Often With an Edge

snippet: The Jets are 10-17 since Idzik was hired as general manager, and the owner, Woody Johnson, will have to weigh his frustration against his confidence in the long-term plan Idzik has charted.
headline: As the Jets Stagger On, John Idzik’s Missteps Become Clearer

snippet: President Obama’s immigration action faces the Congressional spotlight.
headline: Today in Politics

snippet: Economic anxiety amid a dwindling oil and gas industry is raising difficult questions about the future. It is also shaping a Senate race in which a Democrat is seeking re-election in a state long dominated by Republicans.
headline: As Energy Boom Ends, a Political Identity Crisis in Alaska

snippet: The potential political costs of the civil unrest in Ferguson, Mo.; speculation about Chuck Hagel’s replacement; and a look at Speaker John A. Boehner’s turkey brine recipe.
headline: Today in Politics

snippet: After the Jets’ latest embarrassing loss, to the Buffalo Bills, very few people in the organization have job security, least of all Ryan.
headline: Rex Ryan Probably Won’t Survive as Jets Plunge to New Depths

snippet: John Welch, a 51-year-old assistant coach for the Nets, plays aggressive one-on-one defense in practice against the team’s much larger players.
headline: Nets Face Stiff Test; Then the Game Starts

snippet: Britain's status as an island of political stability is coming to an end. Investors and businesses are in for a rough ride.
headline: Investors Should Gird for Political Chaos in Britain

snippet: Democrats worry President Obama can’t close the deal on immigration.
headline: Today in Politics

snippet: The Brooklyn crowd jeered Kidd, the Bucks’ new coach, who had an acrimonious split with the Nets over the summer. But an improving Milwaukee team pulled out a victory at Barclays Center.
headline: As Nets Take On Bucks, the Boos, and the Win, Go to Jason Kidd

snippet: Dr. Daniel W. Johnson, the director of critical care at the University of Nebraska Medical Center, discussed how Dr. Martin Salia died after being brought to the hospital with advanced Ebola symptoms.
headline: Doctor Describes How Ebola Patient Died

snippet: A young woman with a past of hardship and suffering makes a new start in Gilead, Iowa.
headline: Moral of the Story

snippet: A mindless spirit of mild, polysexual eroticism prevails in these photographs of nude men and women in their 20s.
headline: Ryan McGinley: ‘Yearbook’

snippet: Recent gains in controlling the virus have been encouraging, but the world must guard against complacency.
headline: The Shifting Ebola Epidemic

snippet: In Denis Johnson’s new novel, set in Africa, a spy and his ne’er-do-well friend plan to become rich by exploiting post-9/11 politics.
headline: ‘The Laughing Monsters,’ by Denis Johnson

snippet: “Crossing Brooklyn,” at the Brooklyn Museum, showcases artists who live and work in the borough.
headline: The Artist Next Door

snippet: President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf said she would not extend the state of emergency, which had angered critics.
headline: Liberia President, Citing Ebola Gains, Ends State of Emergency

snippet: The Doryen family, unbowed survivors of Liberia’s civil war, saw seven members die from the virus in a matter of months and lost its sense of unity.
headline: For a Liberian Family, Ebola Turns Loving Care Into Deadly Risk

snippet: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A Republican opponent agreed to usher through the Medicare bill in 1964.
headline: 1964: Medicare Foe Says He’ll Act

snippet: In “Landslide,” Jonathan Darman recounts the midterm elections in 1966 as not only signaling the fall of Lyndon B. Johnson, but also the emergence of Ronald Reagan as a national political figure.
headline: How One Presidency Jump-Started Another

snippet: Year-end payouts could drop as much as 10 percent for the trading desks and hedge funds that not long ago were the centers of gravity on Wall Street, according to a survey.
headline: Wall Street’s Bonus Season Not Likely to Be Filled With Joy, Survey Finds

snippet: Two young adult thrillers exploit the conventions of genre to offer head-on critiques of today’s political landscape.
headline: ‘The Doubt Factory’ and ‘Love Is the Drug’

snippet: With citizens’ videos of confrontations with the law proliferating, more police agencies are equipping officers to record their version of events.
headline: Today’s Police Put On a Gun and a Camera

snippet: Living wills would explain how systemically important banks could be resolved in an orderly manner, but a number of challenges still exist, writes Mayra Rodríguez Valladares in Another View column.
headline: Living Wills Still Alive for Regulators

snippet: Officials from an antigraft body cautioned against practicing religion in the eastern province, where several Christian churches have been demolished or forced to remove prominent crosses over the past year.
headline: Party Investigators Warn Officials in Zhejiang Province Against Religion

snippet: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Europeans were happy Lyndon B. Johnson was elected in 1964.
headline: 1964: U.S. Vote Pleases Europeans

snippet: The 29-year-old mother was shopping with her 2-year-old boy and young relatives in Hayden, Idaho, when the boy found a gun in her purse and it discharged once, officials said.
headline: Woman at Walmart Is Accidentally Shot Dead by 2-Year-Old Son

snippet: In Vancouver, Wash., a proposed terminal for oil shipments has led the city and environmental groups to push a builder to quickly finish a competing waterfront real estate project.
headline: Race to Build on River Could Block Pacific Oil Route

snippet: A pair of exhibitions is a must for students of 20th-century design.
headline: ‘The Memphis Group’

snippet: Polymorphous perversity seems to be the thematic principle behind “Disturbing Innocence,” a show with many contributors at Flag Art Foundation.
headline: ‘Disturbing Innocence’

snippet: Six New York art exhibitions and installations explore light, darkness and multiple aspects of enlightenment.
headline: A Profusion of Enlightenment

snippet: The town of Lüliang in Shanxi Province, whose coal helped fuel China’s economic boom, is at the center of a crackdown that challenges the close ties between business and government.
headline: In Limbo, a City in China Faces Life After Graft

snippet: We reflexively think of Ivan Pavlov as the man with the drooling dogs and clanging bell. But a century ago, he was pursuing a more ambitious agenda.
headline: Restoring a Master’s Voice

snippet: Takeshi Murata’s video “OM Rider,” at Salon 94 Bowery, represents the struggle between the avant-garde and the establishment.
headline: Takeshi Murata: ‘OM Rider’

snippet: “Home Movies,” at Postmasters Gallery, is a series of portraits of working-class people struggling in hard times.
headline: Chris Verene: ‘Home Movies’

snippet: The Crusader Bible and the Winchester Bible are vastly different handmade medieval works that will be on display this winter in museums.
headline: Oldest Testaments: A Close-Up View

snippet: Four people were injured in a shooting outside a Portland high school on Friday, throwing an area in the north end of the city into chaos.
headline: Oregon: 4 Hurt in Shooting Near Portland High School

snippet: Engineers in charge of a $3.1 billion tunnel project say that 30 or more nearby buildings have unexpectedly settled.
headline: In Seattle, a Sinking Feeling About a Troubled Tunnel

snippet: Questions remain about the extent to which video can prevent violent citizen encounters or clarify the boundaries of appropriate police response.
headline: Body Cameras Worn by Police Officers Are No ‘Safeguard of Truth,’ Experts Say

snippet: “Selected Stories,” at the Kitchen in Chelsea, includes homemade films, in which Lutz makes cameos as a tiny figure dressed in white.
headline: Klaus Lutz: ‘Selected Stories’

snippet: Places and artifacts connected with celebrated figures from the past make up a show of 82 photographs by Annie Leibovitz, “Pilgrimage,” at the New-York Historical Society.
headline: Bullet Holes to Bones: Artifacts With Meaning

snippet: A multistate analysis concluded that the traditional approach — killing some wolves to reduce their impact on livestock — mostly does not work.
headline: Study Faults Efforts at Wolf Management

snippet: Michael George Patterson tells of his impending death to Alaskan youths, who have been found to not respond to fear-inducing imagery of disease and shortened life.
headline: Antismoking Story That Is Tailored to Native Alaskans

snippet: Photographs by Moby, the pop musician, at the Emmanuel Fremin Gallery in Chelsea, feature a mysterious cult of masked figures.
headline: Moby Presents ‘Innocents,’ a Series of Photographs

snippet: The Norwegian artist Ann Lislegaard presents pieces drawn from science fiction at Murray Guy.
headline: Ann Lislegaard Presents Three Intriguing Pieces

snippet: Mr. Walker had no party, little money and almost no chance of victory just two months before Election Day.
headline: Bill Walker, Next Governor for Alaska, Traversed Unlikely Path

snippet: Mr. Haacke’s show at Paula Cooper includes a sly installation exploring the web of power and money around the Koch brothers.
headline: Hans Haacke

snippet: An exhibition at Matthew Marks centers on the small paintings by the reclusive landscape artist Albert York (1928-2009).
headline: Enigmatic Dreamer’s Flora and Fauna

snippet: Walking through the dark ruins of a defunct Soviet installation brings back memories of the Cuban missile crisis and makes apparent the continuing possibility of a nuclear attack.
headline: A Time for Revisiting Real Fears

snippet: In a town in Oregon that long relied on logging, the old jobs are long gone and the food bank has a more secure future than remaining industry.
headline: Town That Thrived on Logging Is Looking for a Second Growth

snippet: Animal and vegetable references can be seen in Alexander Ross’s “Recent Terrestrials,” his exhibition of paintings at David Nolan.
headline: Alexander Ross: ‘Recent Terrestrials’

snippet: The first major exhibition on Bartholomeus Spranger, at the Met, shows him to be a very good painter who had a knack of being in the right place at the right time.
headline: Artworks of the Flesh Are Manifest

snippet: Senator Mark Begich narrowly lost his re-election bid to Dan Sullivan after a count of absentee ballots.
headline: Dan Sullivan, G.O.P. Senate Challenger in Alaska, Wins Senate Race

snippet: Most of what the city is praised for stems from the big changes of 25 years ago and not the efforts of city administrations since then.
headline: Vibrant, Timid Berlin

snippet: Mr. Hartung’s video “The Bible” sets out to be a contemporary interpretation of the Old Testament.
headline: Tommy Hartung: ‘The Bible’

snippet: A girl develops special powers after she survives a plague in this young adult novel.
headline: Marie Lu’s ‘Young Elites’

snippet: One participant’s experience of Marina Abramovic’s “Generator,” at the Sean Kelly Gallery, in which visitors wear blindfolds and headphones, are led into a gallery and are let go.
headline: A Gallery Show, Site Unseen

snippet: The race for Senate — between Dan Sullivan, a Republican, and the incumbent, Mark Begich, a Democrat — and the vote for governor were still undecided on Wednesday.
headline: Alaska Awaits Election Results for Senate and Governor

snippet: Lessons for both sides of the issue are seen in votes in Alaska, Oregon and Washington, D.C.
headline: New Marijuana Initiatives Loom as 3 Win Approval

snippet: One proposal would impose background checks that go beyond federal law, while the other would expressly forbid an expansion.
headline: Opposing Gun Measures in Washington State Draw Cash and Sow Confusion

snippet: “Bob and Roberta Smith: Art Amnesty,” at MoMA PS1, invites artists to pledge to stop making art and to deposit their work there, raising intriguing questions about how artists and art are valued.
headline: A Disposable Commodity, Indeed

snippet: Alaska, Oregon and Washington, D.C., will decide whether to join Colorado and Washington State in allowing recreational use by adults.
headline: For Marijuana, a Second Wave of Votes to Legalize

snippet: The effort, by Thomas F. Steyer, has turned the battle over the State Senate into one of the most expensive legislative elections in state history.
headline: Trying to Raise Profile of Climate Change for Washington Voters

snippet: The police said Jaylen Ray Fryberg specifically arranged for the five fellow students to gather at the school cafeteria.
headline: Washington School Gunman Used Texts to Gather Victims at Lunch, Police Say

snippet: Details have begun to emerge about the attack, especially on the role of a young teacher many students are calling a hero.
headline: Teacher Is Praised for Her Intervention in Washington School Shooting

snippet: When Jaylen Ray Fryberg pulled out a handgun in the school cafeteria on Friday, according to witnesses, he did not randomly target fellow students, nor authority figures, but friends.
headline: Tangled Portrait of a Student Emerges in Washington Shooting

snippet: Why we are afraid is also why we are safe: News travels quickly.
headline: Ebola’s Information Paradox

snippet: A student gunman was dead after opening fire Friday at a high school near Seattle, killing one and critically injuring four, officials said.
headline: 2 Die, Including Gunman, in Shooting at Washington State High School

snippet: Michelle Grabner’s show at James Cohan Gallery highlights her life as a professor and mother.
headline: Michelle Grabner

snippet: Astronomy is still fending off charges of blasphemy. These days the opposition comes not from the Vatican, but from a people with very different religious beliefs.
headline: Seeking Stars, Finding Creationism

snippet: Johnson may or may not have violated the N.F.L.'s tampering rules in explaining why the Jets did not pursue the Patriots’ Revis in March, when he was a free agent.
headline: Woody Johnson Wants Darrelle Revis to Return. Oops, Sorry.

snippet: Steven Johnson explores the ramifications, good and bad, of six technologies that have changed the world.
headline: ‘How We Got to Now,’ by Steven Johnson

snippet: This exhibition at the Swiss Institute turns chairs into characters in a florid theatrical production.
headline: ‘Fin de Siècle’

snippet: The 26th International Fine Art & Antiques Show at the Park Avenue Armory features more than 65 purveyors of high-end collectibles.
headline: A Collection of Wonders Across the Ages

snippet: “Egon Schiele: Portraits,” at the Neue Galerie, unspools the striking evolution of this Expressionist, who would become one of the 20th century’s most popular artists.
headline: A Rebel’s Feverish Burst of Insolence

snippet: New York sports fans have come to expect men who have successfully built on family fortunes to meddle infuriatingly and fail miserably as team owners.
headline: Silver Spoons, Few Trophies

snippet: A photographer has traveled through Canada’s frozen climes in search of ice huts, primitive, portable shelters built by fishermen.
headline: Freeze Frames of Canada’s Ice Huts

snippet: Dissatisfied with the team’s performance and direction, the owner Woody Johnson fired Ryan after six season as his coach and Idzik after less than two as his general manager.
headline: Rex Ryan and John Idzik Pay for the Jets’ Ineptitude With Their Jobs

snippet: Woody Johnson, the owner of the Jets, discussed why he fired Rex Ryan as coach and John Idzik as general manager, saying, “I thought it was in the best interest of the team to do it.”
headline: Jets Owner Discusses Firings

snippet: Unlike many families that lose touch, families like the Roosevelts and Haneses have used their histories to stay together or, at the very least, guide them.
headline: What the Most Fortunate Learn During the Holiday Season

snippet: The potential hiring of a consultant by the team owner Woody Johnson does not bode well for Coach Rex Ryan, and perhaps General Manager John Idzik as well.
headline: Jets Seem to Prepare for a Potential Overhaul

snippet: It’s time to announce the winners of the Sidney Awards for the best magazine essays of 2014. Part 2 is coming next week.
headline: The Sidney Awards, Part I

snippet: Twin Falls has taken refugees from Vietnam, Eastern Europe and Africa, but residents aren’t sure they want to accept a new group.
headline: Idaho City of Immigrants Debates Taking In Middle Eastern Refugees

snippet: This exhibit focuses on the link between Ed Ruscha and Mason Williams from the late 1950s to the early 1970s.
headline: ‘Double Standard,’ at Alden Projects, Takes a Photographic Trip to the Past

snippet: The artist, who also lived in Paris and Madrid at different points in his life, had his finest hour documenting Puerto Rico, as this show makes clear.
headline: Francisco Oller, Core of ‘Impressionism and the Caribbean,’ at the Brooklyn Museum

snippet: Mr. Obama has criticized Mr. Trump’s plan to deport 11 million unauthorized immigrants, but the president himself has engaged in mass deportation.
headline: Maybe Obama Shouldn’t Lecture Donald Trump

snippet: Though infrastructure is in place, much of it remains empty as Baoding struggles to become a satellite city in Beijing’s megalopolis.
headline: China’s Supercity Policy Keeps Ex-Provincial Capital Waiting for Revival

snippet: Officials said Chris Harper Mercer, 26, went on a shooting rampage in Roseburg, Ore., and that he died after an exchange of gunfire with the police.
headline: Oregon Shooting at Umpqua College Kills 10, Sheriff Says

snippet: A report predicts that bonuses in the financial industry will fall 5 to 10 percent this year, drawing more young talent to a booming Silicon Valley.
headline: Bonus Pay on Wall Street Is Likely to Fall, a Report Says

snippet: Environmental activists celebrated Shell’s announcement that it would suspend drilling for oil in the Alaskan Arctic, while others lamented the potential lost jobs and tax revenue.
headline: Exuberance and Disappointment at Shell’s About-Face in the Arctic

snippet: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Robert C. Weaver voices his desire to run the Department of Urban Development in 1965.
headline: 1965: African-American Seeks Cabinet Post

snippet: The city’s famous air pollution is coming back. So why won’t politicians do anything?
headline: The Return of London’s Fog

snippet: Mr. Johnson’s new Manhattan show explores African-American identity while engaging in rich dialogue with other artists. Here is a visual tour of “Anxious Men” and its influences.
headline: Looking Deeply at the Art of Rashid Johnson

snippet: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Kirk Johnson, KJ Dell’Antonia and others.
headline: What We’re Reading

snippet: More than two dozen people were being treated in Seattle hospitals, many of them in intensive care, a day after a bus packed with international students and a tour bus collided.
headline: College Students Killed in Seattle Bus Crash Were New to the Campus and the Country

snippet: This show at Asia Society showcases the astoundingly skillful work of goldsmiths in the Philippines hundreds of years before the Spanish colonizers arrived.
headline: Review: ‘Philippine Gold: Treasures of Forgotten Kingdoms’

snippet: The lawyers tried to prepare for any legal obstacles — and made it all but inevitable that Bin Laden would be killed, not captured.
headline: How 4 Federal Lawyers Paved the Way to Kill Osama bin Laden

snippet: Four years after the nuclear accident at Fukushima, no one has been killed or sickened by radioactivity. But 1,600 died fleeing the disaster.
headline: When Radiation Isn’t the Real Risk

snippet: Kansas City does something better than any other team in the major leagues: Its batters rarely strike out, which makes it the anti-Cubs.
headline: At the Plate, the Royals Don’t Miss Much

snippet: In preparation for retail marijuana sales on Oct. 1, the state is making it possible for people to have past marijuana convictions removed from their criminal record.
headline: Oregon’s Legal Sale of Marijuana Comes With Reprieve

snippet: The gulf between the East and West conferences persists, but, as Rod Thorn observes, the league should continue trending toward the current successful style, which means a fast tempo and more 3-point shots.
headline: N.B.A.’s Great East-West Divide Remains, but Styles of Play Evolve

snippet: Mr. Johnson said he would not seek re-election after the release of a videotaped police interview with a teenager who said he sexually abused her when he was a basketball player.
headline: For Kevin Johnson, Sacramento Mayor, Abuse Claims Resurface

snippet: Rereading Denis Johnson’s “Jesus’ Son” with Leonard Gardner’s “Fat City” nearby highlights the close relationship between the books in both style and substance.
headline: Influence Looming

snippet: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Nick Corasaniti, Kirk Johnson and others.
headline: What We’re Reading

snippet: The star of the Showtime hit and the secretary of Homeland Security recall their formative years and talk about why spies and actors marry each other.
headline: ‘Homeland’ Times Two: Claire Danes and Jeh Johnson

snippet: An exhibition at Edward Thorp Gallery includes more than 30 kimonos, most from the 1930s and early 1940s.
headline: Review: Illustrated Kimonos Celebrate Japan’s Once Mighty Military

snippet: This exhibit at the Met focuses on sumptuous works produced for the wealthy in the late 19th century.
headline: ‘Artistic Furniture of the Gilded Age’ Recalls Rockefeller and Worsham

snippet: This exhibition of playthings from the 1600s to today shows off Sweden’s woodworking prowess.
headline: Review: ‘Swedish Wooden Toys’ Mix Ingenuity and Education

snippet: In an interview, the China expert describes his deep affection for the Great Wall of China and how he came to write his fifth book on the subject.
headline: Q. and A.: William Lindesay on ‘The Great Wall in 50 Objects’

snippet: Quartersnacks, the chronicle of the New York skate scene, celebrates its 10th anniversary with a new book.
headline: A Downtown Skateboard Blog Turns 10

snippet: C.H.C.M., the popular men’s store on Bond Street, debuts its first collection produced entirely in-house.
headline: A Men’s Wear Staple Expands its Offerings

snippet: The suddenness of the Valley Fire’s surge in Northern California last weekend forced thousands of evacuating residents to leave their animals, both pets and livestock, behind.
headline: Frantic Evacuation in California Left Animals to Face Wildfire Alone

snippet: A man was fatally shot by the police in Miami Beach on Saturday following a brief standoff. The police said the man was a suspect in a bank robbery earlier that day.
headline: Miami Beach Police Shooting

snippet: Alaska expanded federal Medicaid coverage after the state’s highest court on Monday refused an appeal by the State Legislature to halt Gov. Bill Walker’s expansion order.
headline: Alaska: Aided by Governor, Medicaid Coverage Grows

snippet: During a visit to his native Beijing, Mr. Cai discussed classical music, Beethoven’s popularity and why there are so many new concert halls in China.
headline: Q. and A.: Jindong Cai on ‘Beethoven in China’

snippet: This solo show is Mr. Swedlund’s first in New York and includes images of nude women and wooden coins.
headline: Review: Charles Swedlund’s ‘Buy Photographs’ Highlights His 1970s Work
